image.altText: A man with dark hair and sunglasses.

props.synopsis: The distraught sister of missing man Dan Cojocea says she is "hoping for a miracle" as an expanded search continues near Sleaford, south-west of Port Lincoln.

title.children: Sister hoping for 'one-in-a-million miracle' after missing man caught in rip off South Australian beach

image.altText: A photo of sheep  inside a pen

props.synopsis: The federal government orders a live export ship carrying thousands of Australian sheep and cattle to turn back after it was diverted due to the deteriorating security situation in the Middle East.

title.children: Stranded live export ship forced to return to Australia amid deteriorating Middle East security

image.altText: Albanese, pictured at the bottom of the frame, looks up as he walks out of the house of reps

props.synopsis: The prime minister has called Labor MPs back to Canberra nearly two weeks early to discuss ways to ease the pressure on household budgets without adding to inflation.

title.children: All hands on deck as PM calls urgent caucus meeting to tackle cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: A composite image of Peter Malinauskas and Basil Zempilas.

props.synopsis: Earlier this week, SA's premier Peter Malinauskas compared Perth's Test match to "flogging a dead horse". But in a tongue-in-cheek spat, the city's lord mayor has since fired back — by threatening to poach the AFL's Gather Round from Adelaide.

title.children: 'We'll come after Gather Round': Test cricket crowds trigger cross-border slanging match

image.altText: Iga Świątek pumps here right fist at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: World number one Iga Świątek hits Rod Laver Arena for the first match of the night session, with top Aussie Alex de Minaur finding out he will do the same tomorrow at the Australian Open. Follow live.

title.children: Top seed Iga Świątek takes centre stage as Alex de Minaur's next match confirmed

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Live score: Iga Świątek hits centre court to face Linda Nosková
Azarenka completes the comeback and knocks out Ostapenko!
Who does Alex de Minaur play next?

props.synopsis: A missile launched at the Gibraltar Eagle south of Yemen this week failed to do significant damage to the ship, but the militants responsible have made one of the world's most significant shipping lanes a no-go zone.

title.children: How a small group is using YouTube and ingenuity to hurt a quarter of the world's shipping

image.altText: A man stands in front of a orange diesel train engine travelling on the back of a semi trailer

props.synopsis: The Adelaide student loves trains, but he is even more passionate about the community he is building as he takes the sounds and sights of South Australian rail to the world.

title.children: Kane's trainspotting hobby forges friendships and worldwide connections

image.altText: Terry Buckley kneels in a potato field holding some freshly harvested potatoes.

props.synopsis: The humble vegetables are susceptible to storms, heavy rainfall and high temperatures. Frequent extreme weather events make the crop vulnerable.

title.children: Consumers may face more hot-chip potato shortages as heatwaves become more widespread

props.synopsis: Three men have been arrested after more than 40 guns, sophisticated explosive devices and $1 million in cash were seized across Melbourne.

title.children: Firearms, cash and explosives seized in Melbourne, three arrested including alleged Russian organised crime member

image.altText: 7-day cyclone forecast, January 18 2024

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology predicts the slow-moving system will track south or south-westerly over the weekend.

title.children: Cyclone 'more likely than not' will cross Queensland coast next week, possibility of severe category three system

image.altText: A police officer walking with a large package of drugs off a boat at a marina

props.synopsis: Two former drug detectives explain common methods for importing cocaine and why so much ends up in Australia's oceans.

title.children: Former detectives explain the likely reason cocaine worth tens of millions of dollars is washing onto NSW beaches

image.altText: A medium shot of two women walking in front of two men in suits, through the corridor of a musem

props.synopsis: Whether we like it or not, the Middle East conflict already has massive ramifications for debate in Australia. That only increases the pressure on the government over how it conceives our national interest in the issue, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The public doesn’t give a stuff about much of what the government does. That's not true for the conflict in the Middle East

image.altText: Joel Carrett smiles at the 2024 Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Adrian Mannarino isn't your typical professional tennis player, as his laid-back approach to how he's preparing at the Australian Open suggests.

title.children: Meet the 35-year-old French journeyman who credits tequila as the secret to his late-career success

image.altText: a woman holds a ring in both of her hands

props.synopsis: A police campaign raising awareness to human trafficking focuses on teachers, parents and fellow students as they're "often the first to see the signs" of forced marriage — the most common form of the crime.

title.children: Forced marriage cases spike across Australia as schools urged to help identify victims

image.altText: A composite image of two men and a boy

props.synopsis: From secret operations carried out inside Buckingham Palace, to the so-called "mad king" who was restrained and administered drugs laced with arsenic, this is the secret history of royal ailments.

title.children: The secret history of royal illnesses and ailments reveals one simple truth

image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

props.synopsis: Optus and the federal government spent hours during last year's unprecedented outage telling the public triple-0 calls from mobiles should work despite mounting evidence to the contrary behind the scenes, documents obtained under Freedom of Information laws reveal.

title.children: 'You really need to ask Optus': Emails reveal behind-the-scenes chaos during unprecedented outage

image.altText: A screenshot from a video showing tops of trees in the foreground and a plane on fire in the sky in the background, at night

props.synopsis: Investigators say they found a tennis ball-sized hole above one of the plane's engines during a post-flight inspection.

title.children: 'We have an engine fire': Boeing plane's mid-air emergency caught on camera

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: Cailee Spaeny and Jacob Elordi in character as Priscilla and Elvis Presley in front of their wedding cake

props.synopsis: Elvis Presley's estate refused Sofia Coppola permission to use the star's music in her new biopic, and its absence — ensuring the focus remains on Priscilla — turns out to be a blessing.

title.children: Mascara, hairspray and manipulation: Priscilla Presley comes of age as a teen bride to a domineering Elvis

image.altText: Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer shake hands at the net at the 2008 Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Novak Djokovic admits he was not "the favourite type of guy" for many of his rivals when he joined the tour as a teenager, including Roger Federer.

title.children: 'It didn't sit with him well': Djokovic gives insight into early relationship with Federer

image.altText: An historical self-portrait of a female artist at easel, painting a religious scene.

props.synopsis: Sofonisba Anguissola, Lavinia Fontana and Artemisia Gentileschi were renowned in the 16th-century art world, but their achievements were written out of history. A new exhibition lifts the curtain on their extraordinary works.

title.children: These female master artists smashed the glass ceiling in the 1500s, then fell into obscurity – until now

image.altText: A man wearing a grey hoodie with pink writing stares off camera.

props.synopsis: As discussions surrounding menopause increasingly find their place in mainstream conversations, one healthcare worker is creating a podcast exploring what menopause is like for trans men and gender-diverse people.

title.children: For a transgender man going through menopause, Shane feels there aren't a lot of resources out there

image.altText: A graphic showing a puppeteer controlling icons of Facebook, TikTok and Instagram.

props.synopsis: With the chance to make an extra $10,000 a month, Robert has no issue pushing the agendas of presidential candidates online. He's among a growing army of "buzzers" threatening democracy in the lead-up to Indonesia's 2024 elections.

title.children: They have been called 'a virus', but buzzers are part of a fast-growing industry during election season

image.altText: The face of Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, wearing glasses, frowning slightly in front of the Microsoft logo behind him.

props.synopsis: The technology giant says the intrusion started in late November, but was only discovered on January 12.

title.children: Microsoft uncovers email attack by state-backed Russian hackers dating back to November

image.altText: Students exercising at the beach and running up hills training for the Kokoda Track

props.synopsis: They've faced more challenges in life than most, but conquering the Kokoda Track helped show these students they could do anything.

title.children: At the start of this program, some students felt like their lungs were bleeding. They kept coming back

image.altText: a man stands in front of a large dinosaur replica

props.synopsis: Most people scour Facebook Marketplace for a miscellaneous piece of furniture, second-hand appliances or vintage pieces, but social media users have been bewildered by the recent listing of a life-sized titanosaurus.

title.children: It's 4.5m tall and weighs a tonne, and for $58k this life-sized dinosaur can be yours

image.altText: A close up of Madonna, wearing a hat and lacey sleeves, singing into a microphone during a concert.

props.synopsis: Two fans of the Like A Virgin singer say the megastar "has demonstrated flippant difficulty" in performing on time.

title.children: Madonna fans sue singer for starting concerts late, leaving ticketholders 'waiting for hours'

image.altText: Steve Smith plays a shot to the leg side

props.synopsis: Australia coach Andrew McDonald remains optimistic a reshuffled batting line-up will work despite lacklustre returns in the first-Test trouncing of the West Indies.

title.children: Australia maintains faith in new-look batting order, expects greater returns in Brisbane

image.altText: Barry poses with a steely face in a red-checked Louis Vuitton suit adorned with pearls, chains and a ruby earring

props.synopsis: It's past argument that some of the red carpet's more performative trends are going to be picked up by men everywhere and that the spell of the black tuxedo will finally be broken, writes Virgina Trioli.

title.children: Men have taken off the straight jacket — and black tie's dominance is doomed

image.altText: A row of buildings destroyed by air strikes

props.synopsis: A member of Israel's war cabinet casts doubt on the country's strategy for securing the release of hostages held by Hamas. Meanwhile, a communications blackout in Gaza enters its seventh day, the longest such blackout since the war began.

title.children: Rifts emerge among top Israeli officials about how to handle the war in Gaza

image.altText: Young man and woman sit in the brown water of a dam, smiling.

props.synopsis: At least 20 people presented to hospital emergency departments with heat-related issues during this week's blackouts across outback WA. A researcher says it's time to rethink cooling strategies.

title.children: 'We try to put a brave face on it': Kalgoorlie community rallies to help sick, elderly people during four-day blackout

image.altText: Political activist Mongkhon Thirakot flashes the pro-democracy gesture of a three-finger salute.

props.synopsis: The court of appeals found Mongkhon Thirakot, 30, guilty of 25 violations of the law related to posts on Facebook.

title.children: Thailand court sentences activist to 50 years in prison for insulting monarchy on Facebook

image.altText: Image of a front yard with a large replica of the Parthenon built in it.

props.synopsis: David Wadelton has become somewhat of an expert when it comes to front yards. The Melbourne photographer has taken well over 1,000 photos of these cultural touchstones, which he says are disappearing as people knock down old houses.

title.children: 'Echoes of a previous life': One man's mission to capture a part of Australian culture that could soon be gone forever
